claim: Food affordability in America has decreased in recent decades.

supporting.text: The Consumer Price Index for food has increased at a faster rate than general inflation over the past two decades, indicating reduced affordability.

attacks.text: The Consumer Price Index for food has increased at a faster rate than general inflation over the past two decades, indicating reduced affordability.
Wage growth in certain sectors has outpaced food price inflation, offsetting affordability concerns for many households.
Wage growth has been uneven, with lower-income households experiencing stagnant wages relative to food price increases.
Technological advancements in food production and distribution have increased efficiency, partially mitigating price increases.
These efficiencies have not been uniformly passed on to consumers due to corporate profit margins and supply chain costs.

supporting.text: Median household income growth has not kept pace with rising food costs, leading to a higher proportion of income spent on food.

attacks.text: Median household income growth has not kept pace with rising food costs, leading to a higher proportion of income spent on food.
Government assistance programs like SNAP have significantly offset food affordability issues for low-income households.
SNAP benefits are often insufficient to cover a family's full nutritional needs, and eligibility excludes many struggling households.
Technological advancements in agriculture have reduced production costs, partially mitigating food price inflation.
Most cost savings from agricultural tech are captured by corporations rather than passed to consumers through lower prices.

supporting.text: Government data shows a decline in purchasing power for staple food items when adjusted for inflation since the 1990s.

attacks.text: Government data shows a decline in purchasing power for staple food items when adjusted for inflation since the 1990s.
The decline in purchasing power is offset by increased wages and social assistance programs, making food effectively more affordable for many households.
Wage growth has not kept pace with inflation for lower-income households, leaving them disproportionately affected by rising food costs.
The data focuses only on staple food items, ignoring the broader variety of affordable food options available today.
Staple food items are critical for low-income households, and their rising costs disproportionately impact those with limited budgets.
Technological advancements in food production and distribution have reduced costs for many food items, counteracting inflation effects.
These advancements have not uniformly reduced costs for all staple foods, and some items remain significantly more expensive.

supporting.text: The percentage of Americans experiencing food insecurity has risen, suggesting decreased affordability of adequate nutrition.

attacks.text: The percentage of Americans experiencing food insecurity has risen, suggesting decreased affordability of adequate nutrition.
Food insecurity measures access and stability, not just affordability, and may reflect other factors like income volatility rather than food prices.
Studies show food prices relative to income have remained stable or improved for many households, contradicting the direct link between food insecurity and affordability.
Government assistance programs (like SNAP) have expanded, masking true affordability declines by artificially supporting access.
SNAP benefit adjustments lag inflation, meaning even expanded participation doesn't fully offset rising food costs for low-income households.

supporting.text: Real wages for low-income workers have stagnated while food prices have risen, making food less affordable for this demographic.

attacks.text: Real wages for low-income workers have stagnated while food prices have risen, making food less affordable for this demographic.
Government assistance programs like SNAP have expanded, offsetting the affordability gap for low-income households.
SNAP benefits have not kept pace with inflation in food prices, reducing their effectiveness in bridging the affordability gap.
Technological advancements in agriculture have increased food production efficiency, leading to lower relative prices for staple foods.
While staple food prices may be lower, the cost of processed and healthy foods has risen disproportionately, affecting overall affordability.
The rise of discount grocery chains and bulk purchasing options has improved food affordability for budget-conscious consumers.
Many low-income workers lack access to discount grocery chains due to food deserts in urban and rural areas.

supporting.text: The cost of a nutritionally adequate diet, as measured by the USDA's Thrifty Food Plan, has increased faster than inflation since 2000.

attacks.text: The cost of a nutritionally adequate diet, as measured by the USDA's Thrifty Food Plan, has increased faster than inflation since 2000.
The Thrifty Food Plan does not account for regional cost variations, which may show affordability improvements in some areas.
Regional variations are offset by national averages, and the Thrifty Food Plan remains a reliable benchmark for affordability trends.
Wage growth in certain sectors has outpaced food cost increases, offsetting affordability declines for many households.
Wage growth has been uneven, and lower-income households still face disproportionate food cost burdens.
